EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, associated with a powerful storm across Canada, moved across northern New York during the night of February 18th. Strong west to northwest winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts of 40 to 50 mph accompanied the colder air and produced scattered power outages and tree damage across the region. Some reported wind gusts included; 48 mph in Ogdensburg (St. Lawrence county) and 41 mph at Saranac Lake (Franklin county).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong wind gust resulted in the capsizing of a boat on Lake George. There were five people on board the boat, and it was towing two parasailers. It was reported that the boat operator stated he was trying to bring the parasailers down when a gust of wind pushed the riders into some trees and caused the boat to capsize. All on board were wearing life jackets and were helped into other boats or were able to swim to shore. The two parasailers got caught in a tree near Usher Park Beach at the south end of the lake more than 30 feet off the ground. They were freed by members of the Lake George Volunteer Fire Department and treated at the scene.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary from a thunderstorm produced a strong wind gust early Wednesday evening, July 13th, resulting in the capsizing of a boat on Lake George.||Outflow boundary: A storm-scale boundary separating thunderstorm-cooled air, outflow, from the surrounding air. It's passage is marked by a wind shift and usually a drop in temperature.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous spotters reported measured wind gusts in the upper 40s to near 50 mph with scattered downed limbs, isolated trees and power outages throughout the Adirondacks. A report of 55 mph was measured at Lake Clear (Saranac Lake ASOS).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and intensifying area of low pressure moved just north of the St. Lawrence River across southeast Ontario and Quebec provinces in Canada during the night of January 17th and early morning hours of January 18th.||The strong pressure gradient and cold air advection accompanying low pressure and associated cold front accounted for strong to damaging west to southwest winds with gusts in excess of 60 mph in the St. Lawrence River Valley with gusts in excess of 50 mph across most of northern New York. In addition, an earlier ice event still allowed for ice accretion remaining on trees prior to this wind event. Some specific measured wind gusts included;66 mph in Potsdam, 65 mph in Hannawa Falls, 63 mph in Massena (St. Lawrence County), 55 mph in Lake Clear (Franklin county) and Ellenburg (Clinton county).||The end result was numerous tree limbs, trees and power lines down along with thousands without power in the St. Lawrence River Valley with scattered tree limbs, trees and power outages in the Adirondacks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were knocked down due to the strong winds in Crestwood, near the Read Avenue exit ramp off the Bronx River Parkway. In addition, trees were blocking the right lane southbound on the Hutchinson Rover Parkway.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds developed between a retreating offshore high pressure system and an approaching cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were knocked down due to the strong winds at Croton-on-Hudson.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds developed between a retreating offshore high pressure system and an approaching cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a tree down near Clyde.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening southerly wind ahead of a cold front during the morning hours brought measured wind gusts to 45 mph. Across the higher elevations the strong winds brought down some trees and power lines. Specifically, damage was reported near Clyde, Watertown, Adams, New Bremen, Crystal Dale and Middle Branch Settlement.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported trees and wires down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 20 to 30 mph with frequent gusts 35+ mph caused some downed twigs, branches as well as isolated power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane/Superstorm Sandy made landfall near Ocean City, NJ at 8 pm EDT on Monday, October 29th. Sandy was a hybrid storm that allowed for some mid-latitude characteristics, including a large wind field that stretched some 500 miles from the center. This was largely attributed to a 90 mb pressure difference between Sandy's center (945mb) and High pressure (1036mb) in northern Ontario.||In northern New York, a predominant east-northeast wind blew across the region with the strongest winds in the St. Lawrence River Valley, where 20 to 35 mph sustained and wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph were experienced. Elsewhere in northern New York, wind gusts were generally in the 35-45mph range with isolated tree damage and power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 25 to 30 mph with frequent gusts 35-40+ mph caused some downed twigs, branches as well as isolated power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered tree and power line damage due to strong winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure moved across Quebec, while its associated vigorous cold front moved across northern New York during the morning hours of January 20th. Strong to damaging southwest and west winds occurred across portions of northern New York during the morning and early afternoon hours of January 20th.||Numerous reports of tree branches, some downed trees and power lines were reported in the St. Lawrence River Valley and portions of the Adirondacks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured wind gust of 44 mph was recorded in southern St. Lawrence county with several reports of tree, tree limb and power line damage across the region, thus suggesting wind gusts may have exceeded 50 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system rapidly intensified across the Great Lakes on January 30th and moved into Quebec province during January 31st. Mild southerly winds on January 30th translated to colder west to northwest winds across northern New York on January 31st. Sustained winds of 15 to 25-30 mph were observed with several gusts in excess of 40 mph and a few measured gusts exceeding 50 mph.  These strong winds knocked down several tree limbs and a few trees for scattered power outages across northern New York, especially Essex ad Clinton counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured wind gust of 44 mph was recorded in southern St. Lawrence county with several reports of tree, tree limb and power line damage across the region, thus suggesting wind gusts may have exceeded 50 mph.

Sustained winds of 15 to 25-30 mph were observed with several gusts in excess of 40 mph and a few measured gusts exceeding 50 mph.  These strong winds knocked down several tree limbs and a few trees for scattered power outages across northern New York, especially Essex ad Clinton counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured wind gust of 47 mph was recorded at Plattsburgh airport, but tree damage was observed at many locations, suggesting gusts in excess of 50 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Westhampton Beach Airport reported a wind gust of 56 mph at 1240 pm, and sustained winds of 38 mph at 1228 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure developed along a front just to the east and deepened rapidly producing strong winds across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the White Plains Airport in Westchester county measured sustained winds of 38 mph at 955 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure developed along a front just to the east and deepened rapidly producing strong winds across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed a tree which blocked the right lane of the westbound Southern State Parkway.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure approached the area, then slowly moved to the east. Strong gusty winds occurred as this low approached.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at LaGuardia Airport measured a sustained wind of 39 mph at 12:19 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred as low pressure passed to the south and intensified.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at JFK Airport measured a sustained wind of 39 mph at 7:19 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred as low pressure passed to the south and intensified.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Brookhaven Calabro Airport in Shirley  measured a sustained wind of 39 mph at 6:57 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred as low pressure passed to the south and intensified.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Islip MacArthur Airport measured a sustained wind of 39 mph at 6:57 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred as low pressure passed to the south and intensified.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A skywarn spotter reported trees and wires down on Landis Avenue in the Arrochar neighborhood. Damage to cars was reported. This occurred around 10 am. A mesonet reported a wind gust to 57 mph in Tompkinsville around 10 am.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred ahead of a cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The strong winds caused a scaffolding to collapse at West 40th Street and 7th Avenue. There were 4 people reported injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred ahead of a cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered reports of downed tree branches, trees on roads and utility lines in and around Saranac Lake/Lake Clear.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and deepening area of low pressure moved across Ontario and Quebec provinces on November 1st. The associated cold front moved across northern New York during the morning to early afternoon hours and delivered strong southwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts in excess of 60 mph. These winds caused numerous reports of tree branches and trees down as well as on utility lines that caused power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered reports of downed tree branches, trees on roads and utility lines in Clinton county, including Ellenburg, Churubusco.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and deepening area of low pressure moved across Ontario and Quebec provinces on November 1st. The associated cold front moved across northern New York during the morning to early afternoon hours and delivered strong southwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts in excess of 60 mph. These winds caused numerous reports of tree branches and trees down as well as on utility lines that caused power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered reports of downed tree branches, trees on roads and utility lines in Clinton county, including Mooers, Chazy and Plattsburgh.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and deepening area of low pressure moved across Ontario and Quebec provinces on November 1st. The associated cold front moved across northern New York during the morning to early afternoon hours and delivered strong southwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts in excess of 60 mph. These winds caused numerous reports of tree branches and trees down as well as on utility lines that caused power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed due to strong winds in Northumberland.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system moved across southern Canada during the early morning hours on Monday, November 18th.  This was the same storm system repsonsible for a widespread tornado outbreak across the Midwest on Sunday, November 17th.  As the storm's cold front moved across eastern New York, a line of heavy rain showers accompained the boundary.  Within these rain showers, gusty winds of 30 to 50 mph occurred.  This allowed for a few trees to fall across Saratoga County. Although winds remained gusty behind the front through the remainder of the day, no additional damage occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed due to strong winds in Stillwater, Malta and Barkersville.

This allowed for a few trees to fall across Saratoga County. Although winds remained gusty behind the front through the remainder of the day, no additional damage occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds knocked down a large tree around 10 am. The tree downed power lines that blocked Crescent Beach Road by Welwyn Preserve. Bayville reported a wind gust up to 54 mph at 11:17 am.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northwest winds occurred behind a cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several power lines were knocked down in Blauvelt due to strong wind gusts of around 50 mph around 1 pm. These power lines were knocked down near Bradley Parkway and North Greenbush Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northwest winds occurred behind a cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In North Babylon, strong winds knocked down wires and a tree limb on Deer Park Avenue around 5:45 am. This caused power outages across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds in the morning ahead of a cold front shifted to the west.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 6:17 am, a trained spotter reported a wind gust up to 56 mph in Jericho.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds in the morning ahead of a cold front shifted to the west.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:45 pm, the broadcast media reported a large tree limb down on the roof of a car in West Babylon. Wind gusts of 51 mph were observed at Islip McArthur Airport earlier in the day, at 11:36 am.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure over the western Atlantic Ocean resulted in strong northeast winds across the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1:51 pm, the Long Island Office of Emergency Management reported 575 customers without power in North Merrick due to strong winds.  Farmingdale Airport reported wind gusts to 41 kots around that time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds ahead of a cold front occurred across parts of Nassau and Southwest Suffolk Counties on Long Island.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1:34 pm, the Long Island Office of Emergency Management reported 1,064 customers without power in Wyandanch due to strong winds.  Farmingdale Airport reported wind gusts to 41 knots around that time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds ahead of a cold front occurred across parts of Nassau and Southwest Suffolk Counties on Long Island.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1:34 pm, the Long Island Office of Emergency Management reported 661 customers without power in Centre Island due to strong winds.  Farmingdale Airport reported wind gusts to 41 knots around that time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds ahead of a cold front occurred across parts of Nassau and Southwest Suffolk Counties on Long Island.

A sudden gust of wind blew an inflatable bounce house measuring 10 feet by 10 feet in size into the air during the afternoon on May 12th, 2014 at 22 Ferry Blvd in South Glens Falls, New York. Three children inside the bounce house fell out of the house as it blew through the air, including two young boys, who fell from a height of at least 15 feet. The two boys were seriously injured as a result of the incident and were thrown a large distance from the where the accident occurred.  After the children fell out of the bounce house, it blew more than 50 feet through the air and landed in a field of a nearby middle school (Oliver W. Winch Middle School). One boy was hospitalized until late May and the other until mid June with significant injuries.  The maximum wind gust measured that afternoon 2.7 miles away at Glens Falls Airport was 30 MPH.  The weather balloon upper air sounding at Albany that morning suggested winds could gust as high as 40 MPH.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: South winds gusted up to 45 mph, with a peak wind measured at Islip MacArthur Airport of 37 knots.  This occurred at 1044 pm.  Shortly after midnight, a National Weather Service employee reported a large branch was knocked down onto power lines in Centereach.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds occurred across Western Suffolk County ahead of an approaching  cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured gust of 36 knots occurred at Farmingdale Airport at 10:38 pm.  A trained spotter reported power lines down at 10:50 pm, in Lindenhurst near Montauk Highway.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds occurred across Western Suffolk County ahead of an approaching  cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Westhampton Airport, sustained winds of 38 mph, and gusts of 52 mph were measured at 7:15 pm EDT.  At Brookhaven Airport in Shirley, sustained winds of 30 mph were measured at 7:30 pm EDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure passed to the south and east of the area which produced strong winds and isolated flash flooding across portions of New York City and Long Island.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 8:00 pm EDT, a wind gust of 51 mph was reported by a trained spotter in Orient Point.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure passed to the south and east of the area which produced strong winds and isolated flash flooding across portions of New York City and Long Island.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At John F. Kennedy Airport, sustained winds of 31 mph were measured at 9:21 pm EDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure passed to the south and east of the area which produced strong winds and isolated flash flooding across portions of New York City and Long Island.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Islip MacArthur Airport, sustained winds of 36 mph were measured at 10:40 pm EDT.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service Employee reported a utility pole down due to strong winds at 11 am.  The Utility Pole was knocked down onto power lines on route 25 in Middle Island.  Nearby, a wind gust of 52 mph was measured at Islip McArthur Airport at 10:40 am.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure passed south and east of Long Island.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a two mobile homes and a shed in Selkirk as a result of gusty northerly winds.  A resident of one of the mobile homes, who was sleeping at the time, was injured due to the fallen tree.  The mobile home's roof was reported to have sustained major damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure was situated off the coast of the Northeastern United States on Sunday, November 2nd and was moving northeast towards southeastern Canada.  The flow around this storm caused strong north to northwest winds up to 40 MPH across eastern New York.  As a result of these winds, there were reports of tree limbs down, which caused some power outages.  Around 4400 people in Dutchess County lost power as a result of the strong winds.  In addition, one person was injured in Selkirk due to a tree falling into a mobile home.  Winds diminished by the evening hours as the storm moved away from the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Westhampton Airport, a gust of 48 mph was measured at 1:10 pm, with a sustained wind of 35 mph measured at 1:20 pm.  Shirley Airport measured a gust to 46 mph at 10:58 am, and a sustained wind of 32 mph at 1 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure passed south and east of Long Island.

At Islip MacArthur Airport, a sustained wind of 33 mph was measured at 1:59 pm, and a gust of 48 mph was measured at 12:12 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm passed just south and east of the area causing strong winds and heavy rain with flooding in portions of Southeast New York.

Behind a strong cold front on Monday, January 5th, winds became gusty across much of eastern New York.  West to northwest winds gusted up to 40 MPH at times, especially during the morning hours.  These strong winds caused a tree to fall onto a business in Guilderland in Albany County.  The tree downed power lines and a utility pole, causing power to be out for several customers.  Minor damage was also reported to the roof of the business.  The power was restored later that day as winds diminished over the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure deepened as it tracked to the northeast of the area, resulting in strong winds.

In the wake of a frontal system, gusty northwest winds developed due to a strong pressure gradient between the departing storm and an area of high pressure building into the Great Lakes region during the day on Tuesday, March 17th. Wind gusts were frequently recorded over 30 MPH across the region with a few gusts of 40 to 47 MPH across eastern New York. ||These winds downed trees and power lines, causing some power outages across the region.   As the storm continued to pulled away and nocturnal effects began to take over, winds subsided by the late evening hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down in Old Forge due to strong winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a warm front lifted across the region on Monday, April 21st, strong east to southeast winds were in place just above the surface thanks to a tightening pressure gradient and a powerful low level jet.  These winds funneled through the western Mohawk Valley and western Adirondacks during the morning hours, as well as across the high terrain of the Taconics during the late morning through mid afternoon hours. ||Some weather stations in the region noted wind gusts of 35 to 45 MPH.  These winds downed multiple trees and power lines across Herkimer County.  In addition, around 9 trees were downed across the Taconics of eastern Columbia County, especially in the towns of Chatham, Caanan, New Lebanon, Ancram, Hillsdale, and Copake.  These trees blocked roadways and caused some power outages.   Most of the power outages were restored by the morning of Tuesday, April 21st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down in Ohio, Little Falls, Norway and Russia due to strong winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cliinton county emergency management reported several locations that witnessed isolated to scattered tree and utility line damage between 8 and 830 pm. These communites included; Ellenburg, Churbusco and Lyon Mountain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening, intense area of low pressure moved across the Great Lakes into Ontario province Canada on October 28-29th. The resultant pressure gradient between that intensifying low pressure and High pressure near Nova Scotia resulted in storing south-southeast winds of 20-25 mph with some gusts in excess of 40-45 mph. Some isolated tree and power line damage resulted from these strong winds in Clinton and Essex counties in New York.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: New York State Electric and Gas (NYSEG) utility reported scattered tree damage and utility line damage in western Essex county and western Clinton county, including Newcomb.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening, intense area of low pressure moved across the Great Lakes into Ontario province Canada on October 28-29th. The resultant pressure gradient between that intensifying low pressure and High pressure near Nova Scotia resulted in storing south-southeast winds of 20-25 mph with some gusts in excess of 40-45 mph. Some isolated tree and power line damage resulted from these strong winds in Clinton and Essex counties in New York.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed a tree on Mc Kay Road in Amsterdam.  Some power outages were reported throughout the area as well.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought a line of showers to eastern upstate New York during the day on Friday, November 13th.  Some of these showers were accompanied by gusty winds, which downed trees and power lines across parts of the central Mohawk Valley, southeastern Catskills and mid-Hudson Valley. Winds, gusting up to 50 MPH, continued to be gusty in the wake of the cold front through the late evening hours as well.  Local utility companies reported over 6000 customers were without power during the height of the storm, although most of the outages were restored by the next morning.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were reported down in Olivebridge and Wawarsing as a result of gusty winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were reported down in Ulster, Kingston and Plattekill as a result of gusty winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought a line of showers to eastern upstate New York during the day on Friday, November 13th.  Some of these showers were accompanied by gusty winds, which downed trees and power lines across parts of the central Mohawk Valley, southeastern Catskills and mid-Hudson Valley. Winds, gusting up to 50 MPH, continued to be gusty in the wake of the cold front through the late evening hours as well.  Local utility companies reported over 6000 customers were without power during the height of the storm, although most of the outages were restored by the next morning.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed a tree onto a power transmission line on Chestnut Hill Road in Woodstock just before 8 AM EST.  As a result, power was disrupted to over 7,800 customers in eastern Ulster County, with the largest outages reported in Woodstock  and Hurley.  Some others outages were reported in Lloyd, Saugerties, Plattekill, Marlborough, and Kingston.  Most of the power was restored by 11:30 AM EST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the wake of a cold front, westerly winds became gusty across both the eastern Catskills, mid-Hudson Valley and the Mohawk Valley for the daytime hours on Tuesday, December 15th.  The combination of a strong surface pressure gradient and cool temperatures aloft allowed for winds to gust 40 to 50 MPH.  As a result, a few trees and power wires were downed across parts of southern Herkimer and southern Fulton Counties due to these strong winds.  Winds downed a tree in Woodstock onto a power transmission line, which caused a large power outage in Ulster County.  Over 9,000 customers were without power at one point across Ulster County, although most of the power outages were short in duration.||Winds diminished during the evening hours thanks to the loss of daytime heating and surface high pressure building into the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed trees and tree limbs, which caused power outages across the region.  Power was disrupted to over 1,700 customers in western Ulster County, with the largest outages reported in the town of Olive.  Other outages were reported in Wawarsing, Shandaken and Denning.  Most of the power was restored by 11:30 AM EST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained SKYWARN spotter measured a wind gust to 45 MPH at 1:09 PM EST on Kilts Hill in Fairfield.  As a result of these strong wind gusts, a tree and power wires were downed on Stahl Road and Top Notch Road in Fairfield.  Winds also downed wires on Dairy Hill Road and Spruce Drive in the town of Salisbury.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty winds downed power wires at the intersection of Dolge Avenue and Poplar Street in the village of Dolgeville.
